intro: Pectis holochaeta var. holochaeta, commonly known as the narrowleaf pectis, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often with a hairy texture, and it produces small yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. The species is notable for its resilience and ability to thrive in harsh, semi-desert conditions.
